hints.content: There are $\color{green}24\color{black}$ buses in $\color{blue}6$ equal rows.[Same image with the rows numbered 1 through 6 and horizontal lines between the rows][[https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/a5f783ca27df5638fa69de0047459092afc6b1f7.svg]]How can we find out how many buses are in each row?
We can find how many buses are in each row by dividing:$\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ number of rows}\color{black}$So, $\color{green}24}\div\color{blue}6}$
The following expression will tell us how many buses are in each row:- $\color{green}24\color{black}\div\color{blue}6$

The expression $\color{green}30\color{black}\div\color{maroon}5\color{black}$ will tell us how many groups of dogs Kat has to walk.

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ can represent $\color{green}64\color{black}$ total items split evenly into $\color{blue}8$ groups.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}64\color{black}$ into $\color{blue}8$ equal groups?

###MollyWe want to find out how many jellybeans are left, so we subtract $\color{green}64\color{black} - \color{maroon}8$.$\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###DarylWe want to find out how many pencils there are, so we multiply $\color{green}64\color{black} \times \color{maroon}8$.$\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###MarcoWe want to split the $\color{green}64\color{black}$ toys cars evenly into $\color{blue}8$ groups.  So, we divide $\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$.$\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ helps us solve this problem
The expression $\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ can solve the following context:- Marco has $64$ toy cars. He divides them into $8$ equal groups. How many cars are in each group?

question.content: **Which problem can we solve with $64\div8$?**

options: Marco has $64$ toy cars. He divides them into $8$ equal groups. How many cars are in each group?
Molly has $64$ jellybeans. She eats $8$ of them. How many jellybeans does she have left?
Daryl has $8$ bins of pencils. There are $64$ pencils in each bin. How many pencils does Daryl have in all?
correctAnswers: Marco has $64$ toy cars. He divides them into $8$ equal groups. How many cars are in each group?

hints.content:
We can relate division to arrays:
$\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ number of rows}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ number of objects in each row}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ number of objects in each row}\color{black}=\color{blue}\text{ number of rows}}$
There are $\color{blue}3$ rows with $\color{purple}6$ dots in each row.[[image 0]]There are $\color{green}18\color{black}$ total dots.

$\color{green}18\color{black}\text{ total dots}\div ~\color{purple}6\text{ dots in each row}= \color{blue}3\text{ rows}$
$\color{green}18\color{black}\text{ total dots}\div \color{blue}3\text{ rows}  ~=\color{purple}6\text{ dots in each row}$

The following expressions represent the array:- $\color{green}18\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$
- $\color{green}18\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$

hints.content: There are $\color{green}8\color{black}$ bananas total.
There are $\color{blue}2\color{black}$ equal bunches of bananas.

We can think of division as the following:$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of Groups}\color{black}$or$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{maroon}\text{ Size of the Groups}}$
The expression $\color{green}8\color{black}\div\color{blue}2\color{black}$ will tell us how many bananas are in each bunch.

question.content: [[image 0]]There are $8$ bananas divided evenly into $2$ bunches.**Which expression will tell us how many bananas are in each bunch?**

hints.content:
We can think of division as the following: 
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}}$

We know the $\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}$:There are $\color{green}30\color{black}$ books total.And we know the $\color{blue}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$:There are $\color{blue}6$ boxes.
To find out how many books are in each box, we can divide the $\color{green}30\color{black}$ books into $\color{blue}6$ groups.$\color{green}30\color{black}\div\color{blue}6$

question.content: Tom has $30$ books divided evenly into $6$ boxes.**Which expression helps us find out how many books are in each box?**

hints.content:
We can think of division as the following: 
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}}$

We know the $\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}$:There are $\color{green}12\color{black}$ ice cubes.And we know the $\color{blue}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$:There are $\color{blue}2$ cups.

Let's put those numbers in the equation.
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}12\color{black}\div\color{blue}2\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}}$

The quotient will tell us the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$.In this problem, the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$ is the $\color{purple}\text{number of ice cubes in each cup}}$.
The quotient tells us the $\color{purple}\text{number of ice cubes in each cup}\color{black}$.

question.content: Adam has $12$ ice cubes. He divides them equally into $2$ cups.**What does the expression $12\div2$ represent?**

options: Number of ice cubes in each cup
correctAnswers: Number of ice cubes in each cup
